page.title: 04THORNDON COUNTRY PARK 1
page.content: Thorndon Country Park is very large covering an area of about 4 square kilometres. Some parts of the park have very old woodland from the time of the Domesday Book 1086, when it was part of the Manor of West Horndon belonging to the Swain of Essex. As the park was once a Deer Park there are some 500 or 600 year old pollarded oak trees. The trunk was cut above the reach of deer and new shoots could grow without being eaten. One of the trees is called {'The Crinoline Lady'. It has a strange skirt-like growth at the base of the trunk. This may have been caused by the deer rubbing the velvet off their antlers against the tree. The trunk had a girth of 7.30 metres; it took six children and one grown-up to hold hands and reach right round it.
